items.title: DRF: Serializing raises exception
items.body:
I'm trying to use djangorestframework to dynamically return model instances via ajax call. The final call looks like this:
```python
data = {
    'products': products,
}
return JsonResponse(data, status=200)
```
Each of the `product` instances contains two translated fields.
The aforementioned `JsonResponse` call raises
```
/lib/python3.8/site-packages/django/core/serializers/json.py", line 104, in default
    return super().default(o)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/json/encoder.py", line 179, in default
    raise TypeError(f'Object of type {o.__class__.__name__} '
TypeError: Object of type MultilingualQuerySet is not JSON serializable
```

Is there any workaround for this? I have notice [this mixin](https://github.com/deschler/django-modeltranslation/issues/407) but that doesn't work either.

Package versions:
django 3.0.9
drf 3.11.1
django-modeltranslation 0.15.1

items.title: Django does not create migrations to translate models
items.body:
Hi there. I need to translate my site and I decided to use modeltranslation to translate the models. But I have a problem, Django does not see the code to translate and does not create migrations.

# My code

**settings.py**
```python
INSTALLED_APPS = [
    'django.contrib.admin',
    
    ...

    'apps.service',
    'modeltranslation',
]

USE_I18N = True

USE_L10N = True

USE_TZ = True

MODELTRANSLATION_DEFAULT_LANGUAGE = 'en'
MODELTRANSLATION_LANGUAGES = ('en', 'uk')
USE_MODELTRANSLATION = True
```

**model.py**
```python
class Service(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField("Назва сервісу", max_length=200, unique=True)
    content = models.TextField("Опис", blank=True, null=True)
    short_description = models.CharField("Короткий опис", max_length=250, blank=True, null=True)
```

**translations.py**
```python
from .models import Service, Post
from modeltranslation.translator import register, TranslationOptions


@register(Service)
class ServiceTranslationOption(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('title', 'content', 'short_description')

```

When creating migrations, nothing happens.
```bash
$ ./manage.py makemigrations service
No changes detected in app 'service'
```

items.title: Version 0.15 not working with Django 3.0.8
items.body:
`FieldDoesNotExist` is now imported **only** from `django.core.exceptions`

So this line in `manager.py` causing a crash:
`from django.db.models import FieldDoesNotExist`

I saw a fix for this already merged to master:
[PR-553](https://github.com/deschler/django-modeltranslation/pull/553)

Please publish it so we can update our server to Django 3.0.8

items.title: Fallback doesn't work in QuerySet
items.body:
I just want ask if the package should have the functionality described bellow or if this is not supported (fallback in queryset conditions).
I have found this
`https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27418377/django-modeltranslation-queries-fallback`
and it looks so that this functionality is not supported and I have ask like so:
`.filter(Q(title_de = 'hello') | Q(title_en = 'hello'))`
However problem is that it is difficult to know which fallback was used while reading the 'hello' value :(


------- so, description of the behaviour:

0.15, dj3, py3.8.

I have in db:
slug, slug_cs == 'horse-care'
slug_en, slug_de == null

With language "de" reading will return 'horse-care'; which I think behaves properly.
When I ask using QuerySet, `Category.objects.filter(slug='horse-care')` I will receive nothing.

Same happens without MODELTRANSLATION_FALLBACK_LANGUAGES
or with their different settings like:
```
MODELTRANSLATION_FALLBACK_LANGUAGES = ('cs',)
MODELTRANSLATION_FALLBACK_LANGUAGES = {
    'default': ('en', 'de', 'cs',),
    'pl': ('cs',),
}

```
More about the behaviour bellow.
Model is based on django-mptt, so .objects gives MultilingualTreeQuerySet.
I have added .objects2=models.QuerySet.as_manager() which gives standard MultilingualQuerySet.
However both are empty for language "de".
```
# objects2 = models.QuerySet.as_manager()
Category.objects2.get(pk=21).slug_de   # None but same behaviour if ==""
Category.objects2.get(pk=21).slug_cs
# 'horse-care'
Category.objects2.get(pk=21).slug
# 'horse-care'
Category.objects2.filter(slug_de__isnull=True, slug_cs='horse-care')
# <MultilingualQuerySet [<Category: Horse care>]>
Category.objects.filter(slug='horse-care')   # with language: de
# <MultilingualTreeQuerySet []>
Category.objects2.filter(slug='horse-care')   # with language: de
# <MultilingualQuerySet []>
```
queryset.query contains no fallback, just de language:
`SELECT "core_category"."id", "core_category"."slug", "core_category"."slug_cs", "core_category"."slug_en", "core_category"."slug_de", "core_category"."slug_pl",  "core_category"."lft", "core_category"."rght", "core_category"."tree_id", "core_category"."level" FROM "core_category" WHERE "core_category"."slug_de" = horse-care ORDER BY "core_category"."tree_id" ASC, "core_category"."lft" ASC`

items.title: Tests are not working with django2.2 when django files are not writable.
items.body:
Hello guys,

We have test issues with python3-django-modeltranslation when packaging in debian with django2.2.

Build process steps:
  - Install all requirements
  - Run tests
  - If tests are OK, package is created.

Tests permissions problem description:
When package is building, it is expected  that no files are written outside directory where build process is running.
Problem is that tests in django-modeltranslation are trying to write migrations files to /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/django/contrib/auth/migrations/ which is failing, because build process is running under NON-root user, while dependecies are installed under OS pythonpath with   root ownership.

When we were building previous versions of django, we were using this commit as patch https://github.com/deschler/django-modeltranslation/commit/f9d7390eeaf5b7b96aaeaee92bc259a1e9423fdb to make tests work when django files are not writable. Now this patch is not working with django 2.2.

You can reproduce issue by changing ownership to root ( or some other user ) in tox py37-2.2 env and run tests under different user. Applied patch is also not working.

items.title: Admin issue with manually imported object without default translation
items.body:
Hi there,

I have four languages (DE, FR; IT, RM) enabled in my Django (2.2.3) configuration and Django Modeltranslation (0.13.3) running with full standard configuration.

```
LANGUAGES = (
    ("de", gettext("German")),
    ("fr", gettext("French")),
    ("it", gettext("Italian")),
    ("rm", gettext("Rumantsch")),
)

EXTRA_LANG_INFO = {
    'rm': {
        'bidi': False,  # right-to-left
        'code': 'rm',
        'name': 'Rumantsch',
        'name_local': u'Rumantsch',
    },
}

LANG_INFO = {**django.conf.locale.LANG_INFO, **EXTRA_LANG_INFO}
django.conf.locale.LANG_INFO = LANG_INFO
```
When I now import objects trough a management command (from a second DB connected to Django into the default DB) I run in to some problems.

Let's say I import an object into a Model with a translatable `title` field (Required) and this imported object only provides the French title. When I then open this object in the Django Admin the French field is filled in correctly but I can not save the object since the German field is a mandatory field. (Due to the `title` being a mandatory field and the standard behavior of setting the default language as a mandatory field).

So if I want to save that object I have to provide the German translation for this object. But in my case there is no such translation and the application will never need one.

What would be the correct way to import objects that have no German translated title so I can use the admin to edit such objects (without making the title field optional)?

This is how I import the objects:
```
Foo.objects.create(title_de='', title_fr='bar_fr', title_it='', title_rm='')
```

items.body:
```
TypeError: __init__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'on_delete'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "manage.py", line 15, in <module>
    execute_from_command_line(sys.argv)

    return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 2254, in _gcd_import
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 2237, in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 2226, in _find_and_load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 1200, in _load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 1129, in _exec
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 1471, in exec_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 321, in _call_with_frames_removed
  File "lib/python3.4/site-packages/modeltranslation/models.py", line 77, in <module>
    class FieldTranslation(models.Model):
  File "ib/python3.4/site-packages/modeltranslation/models.py", line 125, in FieldTranslation
    creator_user = models.ForeignKey(User, null=True, default=None, related_name='model_translation', verbose_name=u"User translator", help_text=u"User that created last translation version")
TypeError: __init__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'on_delete'
```

I am using django version 2+. it creates migration only if `on_delete` is specified for foreign key relational fields.
And 
`creator_user = models.ForeignKey(User, null=True, default=None, related_name='model_translation', verbose_name=u"User translator", help_text=u"User that created last translation version")`
does not contain on_delete, so it is not allowing me to create migrations.

  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6.8/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/backends/postgresql/introspection.py", line 69, in get_table_description
    for line in cursor.description
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6.8/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/backends/postgresql/introspection.py", line 69, in <listcomp>
    for line in cursor.description
TypeError: sequence index must be integer, not 'slice'
```

I dug into `django/db/backends/postgresql/introspection.py` and found that the method that the management command `sync_translation_fields` calls (`get_table_description`) fails in Django 2.1 possibly due to [this change in introspection.py about a year ago](https://github.com/django/django/commit/f3a98224e6dd5f8846008512f281e452dc3b1909#diff-7f14932a08ce1dbba14da7433e47f9fcL78)

items.title: _base_manager shouldn't be MultilingualManager?
items.body:
I just found the below code show the error: 
`django.db.utils.IntegrityError: (1062, "Duplicate entry 'xxx' for key 'PRIMARY'")`

```
class MyManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self):
        return super().get_queryset().filter(is_hidden=False)

class MyModel(models.Model):
    objects = MyManager()

item = MyModel.objects.create(is_hidden=True)
item.is_hidden = False
item.save()
```

It seems that the `save` method calls the default manager, and I just checked the django code and found the error is due to the override of the _base_manager. It's doing the query with `MultilingualQuerySet` which is using my custom query set.

https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/db/models/base.py#L841

Any suggestion?

items.body:
I'm in the process of upgrading a Django 1.11 project to 2.0. During this, I've also had to upgrade to DMT 0.13-beta1.

When running my tests, I get a few errors like this:

```
======================================================================                                                                                                                                      [82/1422]
ERROR: test_phone_exceptions (address_book.tests.test_serializers.SerializerTestCase)                                                                                                                                
----------------------------------------------------------------------                                                                                                                                               
Traceback (most recent call last):                                                                                                                                                                                   
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/unittest/case.py", line 58, in testPartExecutor                                                                                                                                           
    yield                                                                                                                                                                                                            
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/unittest/case.py", line 600, in run                                                                                                                                                       
    testMethod()                                                                                                                                                                                                     
  File "/vagrant/code/address_book/tests/test_serializers.py", line 142, in test_phone_exceptions                                                                                                                    
    s.save()                                                                                                                                                                                                         
  File "/home/ubuntu/.virtualenvs/whnue-api/lib/python3.5/site-packages/rest_framework/serializers.py", line 209, in save                                                                                            
    self.instance = self.update(self.instance, validated_data)                                                                                                                                                       
  File "/vagrant/code/address_book/serializers.py", line 338, in update                                                                                                                                              
    self.update_phone_numbers(instance, phone_numbers)                                                                                                                                                               
  File "/vagrant/code/address_book/serializers.py", line 280, in update_phone_numbers                                                                                                                                
    flat=True                                                                                                                                                                                                        
  File "/home/ubuntu/.virtualenvs/whnue-api/lib/python3.5/site-packages/django/db/models/manager.py", line 82, in manager_method                                                                                     
    return getattr(self.get_queryset(), name)(*args, **kwargs)                                                                                                                                                       
  File "/home/ubuntu/.virtualenvs/whnue-api/lib/python3.5/site-packages/modeltranslation/manager.py", line 486, in values_list                                                                                       
    clone = self._values(*fields, prepare=True)                                                                                                                                                                      
  File "/home/ubuntu/.virtualenvs/whnue-api/lib/python3.5/site-packages/modeltranslation/manager.py", line 451, in _values                                                                                           
    new_fields, translation_fields = append_fallback(self.model, original)                                                                                                                                           
  File "/home/ubuntu/.virtualenvs/whnue-api/lib/python3.5/site-packages/modeltranslation/manager.py", line 89, in append_fallback                                                                                    
    opts = translator.get_options_for_model(model)                                                                                                                                                                   
  File "/home/ubuntu/.virtualenvs/whnue-api/lib/python3.5/site-packages/modeltranslation/translator.py", line 652, in get_options_for_model                                                                          
    'translation' % model.__name__)                                                                                                                                                                                  
modeltranslation.translator.NotRegistered: The model "PhoneNumber" is not registered for translation
```

The model `PhoneNumber` is not registered for translation, as the error correctly says. But I'm not trying to access anything related to translation on this model. I get the same error for a couple of other models that are also not registered for translation.

I've noticed something in common for these cases: They are all related to calling `values`/`values_list` – the latter, potentially with `flat=True` – on a set of objects related to something.

In the above case, it's a set of `PhoneNumber`s related to an instance of a `BusinessCard` model:

```
existing_phone_number_ids = list(instance.phone_numbers.values_list(    
    'id',                                                               
    flat=True                                                           
))
```

I'd love to provide more info, but for now this is all I have. I'm trying to construct a small testcase to prove the problem. But I thought the referenced files/lines from the failed test might be helpful to someone familiar with this project, so I'd rather report early :)

I suspect it may be related to [this `if` in `values_list` in `manager.py`](https://github.com/deschler/django-modeltranslation/blob/91cb5fb0fad9f559a015bdacf49ca42fa87a324a/modeltranslation/manager.py#L485). The same `if` pattern is found in `values`. But I honestly don't really have any credible clues, as I don't understand the internals of DMT (yet).

items.title: get_fields() is not called by TranslationAdmin
items.body:
To make the Django admin only display a subset of model fields, sometimes it's useful to override `ModelAdmin.get_fields()`(which returns a list of fields) instead of just hardcoding `fields = [...]`. For example, if the set of admin fields depends on the object dynamically in some way.

This works when inheriting from the builtin `admin.ModelAdmin`, but `TranslationAdmin` does not seem to ever call `get_fields()`. Instead, the admin page just continues to show all fields.

```
class MyModelAdmin(TranslationAdmin):

    fields = ['foo', 'bar']  # Works

    def get_fields(self, request, obj=None):
        return ['foo', 'bar']  # Doesn't work, get_fields is never called
```

items.title: NotRegistered: The model "Permission" is not registered for translation
items.body:
After spending ~8hrs of time figuring out the problem, and after a nonsensical pull request, I can report I've found an issue:

I have a translated `InheritedPermission` model inherited from django's `Permission`, on which I use some translated fields.

When accessing the `Permission` with `has_perm` from the user angle, modeltranslation explodes. Probable cause is the `Permission.objects` manager gets replaced after expiring the relations cache, which can happen on various occasions (at my project it happens at initialization time).

I've created a test in my fork that reproduces the bug: see #466 and the latest failing commit.

@deschler, can we get a quick fix and a release? modeltranslation not being released for Django 2.x is the biggest blocker for me from changing to Django 2.

items.title: base_manager uses default_manager
items.body:
In our project we figured out that overwriting the base_manager_name is not a good idea.
model._meta.base_manager_name = 'objects'
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/topics/db/managers/#base-managers
https://github.com/deschler/django-modeltranslation/commit/a7b484d10aa16003a7d912332744699fbbc23014

Since now it gets set to the normal objects manager, whatever is done there now also happens in the related lookups. When you now use your own manager (that use extra filtering) on a model that also uses modeltranslation, related lookups (can) break

items.title: How to combine django-modeltranslation and django-reversion apps?
items.body:
Is it possible to combine django-modeltranslation and [django-reversion](https://github.com/etianen/django-reversion) apps?

I have next problem: in `models.py` file I registered (`@reversion.register()`) `Slide` model which has `head` field. This field has several other fields for translation like `head_ru`, `head_kz`, `head_en`. I set these fields in `translation.py` and `settings.py` files. In DB slider table has all this fields. Also I show all this fields in form where user can edit data. When user submit the form django-reversion or django-modeltranslation create version only for head field and ignore other fields. How to fix this problem? 

**models.py:**
```
from django.db import models
import reversion

@reversion.register()
class Slide(models.Model):
    head = models.CharField(verbose_name='Title', max_length=200, blank=False,)
```

**translation.py:**
```
from modeltranslation.translator import TranslationOptions
from modeltranslation.translator import translator
from .models import Slide

class SlideTranslationOptions(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('head',)

translator.register(Slide, SlideTranslationOptions)
```

**settings.py:**
```
LANGUAGES = (
    ('ru', 'Russian'),
    ('en', 'English'),
    ('kz', 'Kazakh'),
)
```

**views.py:**
```
class SlideEditView(RevisionMixin, UpdateView):
    template_name = 'slider/edit_slide.html'
    form_class = SlideForm
    model = Slide

    def form_valid(self, form):
        form.save()
        data = dict()
        data['form_is_valid'] = True
        context = {'slides': Slide.objects.all(),}
        data['html_slides'] = render_to_string('slider/slides.html', context)
        reversion.set_comment('EDIT')
        return JsonResponse(data)
```

items.title: Issues with complex M2M relationships
items.body:
Hi,

I'm using [django-oscar](https://github.com/django-oscar/django-oscar) with django-modeltranslation, and I have a few issues with some classes in its [catalogue](http://docs.oscarcommerce.com/en/latest/ref/apps/catalogue.html) app. I'm translating the `name` and `description` fields in the `Category` class.


# Models and their relationships
Models hierarchy:

    MP_Node ---> AbstractCategory ---> Category

          AbstractProductCategory ---> ProductCategory

                  AbstractProduct ---> Product

`AbstractCategory` is an abstract model that inherits from `MP_Node`, another abstract model from [django-treebeard](https://django-treebeard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mp_tree.html). This makes it possible to easily define hierarchies of categories, and extend Oscar's `AbstractCategory` model in the user's code. `MP_Node` uses a custom manager, and `Product` has two simple custom managers as well (defined in `AbstractProduct`).

The `Category` model is then linked to the `Product` model via the `ProductCategory` model:

    categories = models.ManyToManyField("catalogue.Category, through="ProductCategory")

Again, in Oscar they actually are defined as simple children of the `AbstractProduct` and `AbstractProductCategory` models.


# The issue
Now, in my code, I want to search products that have certain categories, by category name:

    products = Product.objects.filter(categories__name = "Foo")

This doesn't work, and when logging the SQL queries it's easy to see why:

    SELECT * FROM "catalogue_product" 
    INNER JOIN "catalogue_productcategory" ON ("catalogue_product"."id" = "catalogue_productcategory"."product_id")                                                                                                                                                          
    INNER JOIN "catalogue_category" ON ("catalogue_productcategory"."category_id" = "catalogue_category"."id")
    WHERE "catalogue_category"."name" = 'Foo'         

The `WHERE` clause does the search on `name` instead of `name_fr`... So no good results.


# Workaround
After reading some other issues, especially #389, I came up with a workaround:
- redefine the `Category` custom manager (`objects = MP_NodeManager()`, like in `MP_Node`)
- extend the managers from `AbstractProduct`, make them inherit from `MultilingualManager`, and add them to `Product`

Now everything works as expected and my tests pass :)

However, I think that:
- if this behavior is expected, it should be documented somewhere
- if it's not, well, it should work without needing further modification of unrelated models and managers.

Sorry for the very long issue. I hope it's clear enough; if not please tell me which parts I should improve. I'll try to come up with a short repro one day, but I'm a little busy at the moment...

Thanks!

items.title: Django 1.10 default manager not MultilingualManager for model inheriting abstract class with a manager defined on objects (leading to AttributeError: 'QuerySet' object has no attribute 'rewrite')
items.body:
Whilst upgrading my application to Django 1.10 I came across the following issue where the default manager for a Model Translation registered model didn't get dynamically set to `modeltranslation.manager.MultilingualManager`.

This resulted in an exception being thrown in [update_translation_fields.py L32](https://github.com/deschler/django-modeltranslation/blob/master/modeltranslation/management/commands/update_translation_fields.py#L32)

`AttributeError: 'QuerySet' object has no attribute 'rewrite'`

A similar issue was resolved in #123 but it seems something in the internal changes in Django 1.10 has resurfaced it in the particular scenario I have (not one covered by #381).

I haven't yet identified what the changes are that cause it but I've narrowed the scenario down to one in which a model inherits from an abstract model that explicitly sets a manager via the  `objects` attribute. In this case the resulting `_default_manager` is that set on `objects` rather than `modeltranslation.manager.MultilingualManager`.

The simplest example I can boil it down to is this:

```
# models.py

class FooAbstract(models.Model):
    class Meta:
        abstract = True

class Foo(FooAbstract):
    name = models.CharField(blank=True, max_length=1)

class Bar(models.Model):
    objects = models.Manager()
    name = models.CharField(blank=True, max_length=1)

class BazAbstract(models.Model):
    objects = models.Manager()
    class Meta:
        abstract = True

class Baz(BazAbstract):
    name = models.CharField(blank=True, max_length=1)


# translations.py

@register(Foo)
class FooTranslationOptions(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('name',)

@register(Bar)
class BarTranslationOptions(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('name',)

@register(Baz)
class BazTranslationOptions(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('name',)


# shell

from modeltranslation.translator import translator
models = translator.get_registered_models(abstract=False)
for model in models:
    print(model.__name__, type(model._default_manager))

# Django 1.9 output:

Foo <class 'modeltranslation.manager.MultilingualManager'>
Bar <class 'modeltranslation.manager.MultilingualManager'>
Baz <class 'modeltranslation.manager.MultilingualManager'>

# Django 1.10 output:

Foo <class 'modeltranslation.manager.MultilingualManager'>
Bar <class 'modeltranslation.manager.MultilingualManager'>
Baz <class 'django.db.models.manager.Manager'>
```

I don't have a solution yet but thought I'd submit it as an issue now in case anyone has any ideas?

MODELTRANSLATION_FALLBACK_LANGUAGES = ('en', 'fr')
```

And we execute the following code:

```
my_object = MyObject.objects.create()

# Assign a value ONLY to name_fr
my_object.name_fr  = 'some_fr_name'

# Here is the line that causes the problem!
my_object.full_clean()
my_object.save()

#
my_object.refresh_from_db()
print my_object.name_en   # print 'some_fr_name'!
```

So the problem is that `name_en` is updated even if we only specify the value of `name_fr`! If you remove the French from fallback values, or if you don't do the full clean, it works fine. It also works fine if `name_en` had a value before.

items.title: Rule 2 (Assigning a value to the original field ...) broken for Deferred models

Translated models doesn't return flat annotated values_lists
items.body:
Translated models returns list of tuples when queryset is build as `values_list(...,  flat=True).annotate(...)`. Expected behaviour is to return list of values regardless of the order of `values_list` and `annotate` calls.

Found using django-modeltranslation 0.11 and django 1.7 and 1.8
##### Example

``` python
# Untranslated model
>>> Foo.objects.values_list('year', flat=True).annotate(Count('year'))
[1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, ...]
# Translated model
>>> Bar.objects.values_list('year', flat=True).annotate(Count('year')) # Unexpected result
[(1991, 2), (1992, 1), (1993, 5), (1994, 7), ...]
# Same output is given when `flat` is not used
>>> Bar.objects.values_list('year').annotate(Count('year'))
[(1991, 2), (1992, 1), (1993, 5), (1994, 7), ...]
```

_Edit: I removed the cases `annotate(...).values_list(...)`, because it performs different queries, both in django and modeltranslation._

items.title: Django ModelTranslation local fields clash with parent´s model fields
items.body:
I´m developing a website with Mezzanine and I´m having problem trying to configure modelTranslation plugin for it.I´m using Django 1.8.9 and Mezzanine 4.0.1, django_modeltranslation 0.11.

I have a model class GenericContent with some fields :

```
class GenericContent(models.Model):
    image_footer = RichTextField(blank=True)
    video_footer = RichTextField(blank=True)
    summary = RichTextField(blank=True)

class BasicContent(Page, RichText, GenericContent):
    pass
```

In the translation.py file for the basicContent app, we have the following modelTranslation translation definitions :

```
class TranslatedGenericContent(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('summary',
              'image_footer',
              'video_footer',)`

class TranslatedBasicContent(TranslationOptions):
    pass
```

```
translator.register(GenericContent, TranslatedGenericContent)
translator.register(BasicContent, TranslatedBasicContent)
```

With this configuration, it doesn´t show errors, but the basicContent doesn´t get translated(the inherited fields from genericContent are registered for translation, but in basicContent they don´t get translated, nor any other fields from the parent classes[Page and RichText], which are Mezzanine included classes and registered for translation).

If I try to modify the translation.py file :

```
class TranslatedGenericContent(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('summary',
              'image_footer',
              'video_footer',)`

translator.register(GenericContent, TranslatedGenericContent)
translator.register(BasicContent, TranslatedGenericContent)
```

This other configuration gives and error when trying to run python manage.py sync_translation_fields

```
basicContent.BasicContent.image_footer_en: (models.E006) The field 'image_footer_en' clashes with the field 'image_footer_en' from model 'basicModels.genericcontent'.
basicContent.BasicContent.image_footer_es: (models.E006) The field 'image_footer_es' clashes with the field 'image_footer_es' from model 'basicModels.genericcontent'.
basicContent.BasicContent.summary_en: (models.E006) The field 'summary_en' clashes with the field 'summary_en' from model 'basicModels.genericcontent'.
basicContent.BasicContent.summary_es: (models.E006) The field 'summary_es' clashes with the field 'summary_es' from model 'basicModels.genericcontent'.
basicContent.BasicContent.video_footer_en: (models.E006) The field 'video_footer_en' clashes with the field 'video_footer_en' from model 'basicModels.genericcontent'.
basicContent.BasicContent.video_footer_es: (models.E006) The field 'video_footer_es' clashes with the field 'video_footer_es' from model 'basicModels.genericcontent'.
```

Have you ever experienced this problem? I´m looking into a fix for this. Any help would be appreciated!

items.title: Philosophical question about having duplicated datas in the DB
items.body:
Hi, 

I'm about to choose an application to translate an existing project and I've tried django-modeltranslation, which is excellent, bravo ! 

I have a doubt about something and after reading the doc, I'm not 100% sure I've got it. 
My project is french and all the content in the DB is written in french. I will add the english language (I already have i18n and localisation files).

After setting this : 

``` python
MODELTRANSLATION_DEFAULT_LANGUAGE = 'fr'

@register(MyModel)
class MyModelTranslationOptions(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('title', )
```

The migration will create : **title_fr** and **title_en**. 
I can't explain why I need to have a both title + title_fr fields that will normally have the same value 100% of the time. Having duplicated datas in the DB is source of errors. 
I've searched in many places to know why, with no success. 

Thanks for reading.

items.title: group_fieldsets leaves ManyToMany fields out
items.body: When using group_fieldsets, ManyToMany fields are not displayed in the admin anymore. I think this happens because ManyToMany fields are not listed in Model._meta.fields.

items.title: modeltranslations break ORM datetimes()
items.body:
From https://github.com/stephenmcd/mezzanine/issues/1359

``` python
In [24]: BlogPost.objects.filter(**{ 'publish_date__year':2015, 'publish_date__month':7}).datetimes('publish_date','day')
Out[24]: [(datetime.datetime(2015, 7, 21, 0, 0, tzinfo=<UTC>), datetime.datetime(2015, 7, 21, 0, 0, tzinfo=<UTC>))]

In [25]: BlogPost.objects.count()
Out[25]: 1

In [26]: BlogPost.objects.first().publish_date
Out[26]: datetime.datetime(2015, 7, 21, 22, 28, 8, tzinfo=<UTC>)
```

items.title: Creation of an option to prevent specifics URLs to have a language slug
items.body:
It would be a good idea to create some kind of parameter that allows preventing specific URL patterns from have a language slug and being translated. This would be because some URLs (like the ones for dynamically generated sitemaps in XML) are not necessary to be translated, and it is an inconvenient that they get forced to have an '/en/' like slug for languages in the URLs. In addition, it ends up creating two different sitemaps for each language.

I've read all the CHANGELOG entries to find out if this feature already exists or not, but it seems it doesn't.

items.title: Admin list_editable tabbed widget
items.body: Is it possible to add an editable tabbed text area in the admin list view?

items.title: AttributeError: 'Options' object has no attribute 'module_name' in Django 1.8
items.body:
python manage.py sync_translation_fields command:

File "/django_1.8/lib/python2.7/site-packages/modeltranslation/management/commands/sync_translation_fields.py", line 70, in handle_noargs
    model_full_name = '%s.%s' % (model._meta.app_label, model._meta.module_name)
AttributeError: 'Options' object has no attribute 'module_name'

In Django 1.8 Model._meta.module_name was renamed to model_name.

items.title: Model inheritance and translation
items.body:
Hello, I noticed that my models with translation using inheritance were broken with the upgrade to Django 1.8.

I setup a minimal test case on a new project and find a similar issue.

``` python
# models.py
class BaseQuestion(models.Model):
    label = models.CharField(max_length=400, null=True, blank=True)  # Translated
    position = models.IntegerField(default=0)


class QuestionScale(BaseQuestion):
    low_anchor = models.CharField(max_length=100, null=True, blank=True)  # Translated


class QuestionMultiChoice(BaseQuestion):
    multiple_answer = models.BooleanField(default=False) 
    # Nothing is translated for this class

# translation.py
class BaseQuestionTranslationOptions(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('label',)

translator.register(BaseQuestion, BaseQuestionTranslationOptions)


class QuestionScaleTranslationOptions(TranslationOptions):
    fields = ('low_anchor',)

translator.register(QuestionScale, QuestionScaleTranslationOptions)
```

So when I open my shell and type

``` python
>>>question_scale = QuestionScale(label='This is a test')
>>>question_scale.save()
>>>question_scale.label_en
'This is a test'
>>>question_multichoice = QuestionMultiChoice(label='This is also a test')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/remi/.virtualenvs/debug/lib/python2.7/site-packages/modeltranslation/translator.py", line 213, in new_init
    old_init(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/remi/.virtualenvs/debug/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/db/models/base.py", line 480, in __init__
    raise TypeError("'%s' is an invalid keyword argument for this function" % list(kwargs)[0])
TypeError: 'label_en' is an invalid keyword argument for this function
```

So maybe it comes from the way I declare my translations, maybe QuestionMultiChoice is supposed to be declared in there (which field should I put? Since I don't have any translation for that child class...).

Thanks.
